title: This thing burns - literally and figuratively
content: Installed this on a Z390 Gigabyte Aorus Master, under a Corsair h115i with Conductonaut like Tom's Hardware said to do.  Out the box it's running 4.9 for 1 core, 4.8 for 2-4 cores, and 4.7 for more than 4 cores.  Without tweaking any settings, voltages are in the mid 1.2's.  In general gaming use, temps run in the mid-50s with this rig, but the XTU benchmark can push them into the 60s.  A few half-hearted attempts at overclocking reveal that this chip, like many of its kind, isn't particularly happy with AVX over 4.7, and some of the cores seem more susceptible to this than others.  Still, I couldn't get it over 80 degrees C; platform instability happened first, at 5.1 with an AVX offset of -2.  (5.1 at -3 ran at 1.4 with not much other tweaking required).  Combined with a couple Samsung NVME drives (512G Evo and 1TB Pro) and some 3200 GHz LED RAM, boot times are superfast (with Fast Boot on) - blink and you miss it.I was able to push a 7680x1440 three-monitor rig to 60 fps minimum in GTA Online; average framerates were in the 90s, though nVidia Surround had me limited to 60 Hz.  The same 1080Ti could only do 23 fps minimum with my prior rig, which was Z77/3770K@4.4 GHz based.Nearly any other game I can push my ROG PG279Q to its full framerate of 165 Hz without difficulty.  I like to play Rocket League at 250 fps to minimize input lag and was pleasantly surprised to find that I could keep it over 200 and still get what that game calls "quality" graphics on both the single-monitor and triple-monitor setups.  I'm old enough that I'll take whatever edge I can get!Install was a snap, watch a video if you're worried about it.  Computer booted fine the first time I turned it on - if you can turn a screwdriver you can build a PC.  And this processor is the one to get - I expect to be future proof for many years!

title: Hot hot hot!
content: Despite advertising the 3.6GHz stock speed, in reality the processor runs 4.7GHz all core turbo / 5.0 GHz single or dual core turbo out of the box, without you touching anything in the BIOS. More speed is usually a good thing so why is this a con? Well because it is not designed to handle that much power and heat.At 4.7GHz all core turbo most hardware monitor will show CPU drawing over 130 watt, 50% above its TDP. I have seen as high as 147 watt with certain motherboards.Some of the cheaper Z390 motherboards don't even have the power delivery to sustain 4.7GHz all core turbo, like the ASRock Z390 Pro4 and ASRock Z390M Pro4. If you run any CPU stress test for over 15 minutes you will see the turbo speed throttled down to 3.6-3.7GHz, which is probably what the processor is originally designed to run at. However at the last second Intel decided to slap on a 4.7GHz all core turbo due to pressure from Ryzen CPUs.More power comes more heat. Based on silicon lottery (stock voltage varies from 1.19V to 1.41V from my observation) some chips can rapidly climb to high 90 or even 100 Celsius during stress tests with 120mm AIO in a well ventilated case like MeshifyC. I have never seen 120mm AIO failed to handle a CPU at stock speed over 20 years. Even the notorious FX-9590 wasn't this hot. If you don't want to mess with BIOS or win the silicon lottery, 240mm AIO is a must and the worse chips can still hit 90 Celsius. I had to manually lower the voltage and run a lot of stress tests to keep some of them sustainable over long term usage, huge amount of time wasted!

title: A decent gaming CPU, marred by Intel design choices and pricing
content: Let's be clear here: The 9700K is second only to the 9900K (at the time of writing) for pure gaming performance. The 3rd-gen Ryzen CPUs are getting close, but they still don't match Intel in CPU-intensive titles like Arma 3, which led me to this CPU.With that out of the way: for gaming specifically, there's not much to complain about with the 9700K. It performs well - a notable step up from the i7-4790 I previously used - and I've had no issues yet with it. But I really would lean towards AMD/Ryzen in most use cases, particularly with regards to workstation purposes (as the 9700K conveniently lacks hyperthreading - thanks, Intel) and multitasking/streaming.With these caveats mentioned, I can't really give the 9700K a particularly bad score. It's... fine? I wouldn't purchase it for more than $350 USD, as it does lack hyperthreading, and I would probably even shy away from Intel's 10th-gen offerings for their supposed inefficiency and (unnecessary) new motherboard chipset. But I'm using this CPU primarily to power CPU-intensive games, and for that purpose specifically, the 9700K still pulls ahead, at least for the time being.

title: 8 Threads for How Much???
content: This is an 8 thread processor. That will be a problem for many people, and not just the creative users (who would never want this) but also some gamers. If you are a gamer that only runs the game, in a sterile windows environment, then this might be the CPU for you.Keep in mind, however, that most users will have a lot more than just the game running in windows. When I’m gaming there are several applications left up plus 300+ processes over thousands of threads, and the windows scheduler spreads all those threads across my 16 threaded CPU, keeping them away from the 4-8 threads my game uses. What that means is that I can just launch the game any time I want, and the game isn’t effected by all the other crap I have running. For instance, if my virus scanner decides to start up a system check, it does not matter.Now, if I had this 8 thread CPU, there would be a hit. It might only be 10%, but the question is, why should I get this when I can get a 12 thread 8700k or 16 thread 3700x and have better real world performance for the same price? The 3700x even comes with a cooler. I feel like this CPU exists only for clean benchmark tests; it’s not a daily driver. The only thing I can think of is a niche use case, like a system that has only one purpose, like a flight simulator at a school where the PC really only does that one thing. In that case it’s cheaper than a 9900k and faster than a 8700k. The presence of the 3700x, however, really makes this offering from intel a tough sell. If this were $199, it would be a good option, but at $330, it’s outclassed today, and will continue to decline as your computer ages (and more and more threads are added to its workload)
date: Reviewed in the United States on November 9, 2018

title: Top of Line Product, for Top of the Line Price!!!
content: As someone in the reviews (Why are you supporting this)? tries to make people believe that "More threads is always better" ... Well, ITS NOT! A faster physical core is ALWAYS more important than a single thread. This CPU is AMAZING for anything. Especially gaming! Which is utilized for 8 cores. Hyperthreading makes no difference if the games only support 8 cores anyways. There is absolutely no game or program this 9700k won't completely destroy. These are VERY FAST cores with no hyper threading. If you want a workstation and you want the best, get the 9900k and you will have the most powerful CPU on the block. If you are building for a gaming rig specifically, Get the 9700k... AMD shouldn't even be in the question unless you are on a tight "Budget"... it's that way for a reason. You have to pay to play. AMD has never been the best for gaming, nor will it be. Intel has always been a premium price for a reason. It's simply due to the fact they have faster cores. If you are trying to build a beast gaming PC, Just go look at scores produced in the top charts = Always Intel!You can't go wrong with the 9700k or 9900k. Just make sure you have adequate cooling as with any CPU pushing 5.0ghzFinal Note = Intel chipsets are ALWAYS days beyond any AMD or Ryzen. You don't have to worry about all the sensitivity to RAM speeds ect. Just buy an Intel, and you know you are getting a tried and true product. There is nothing wrong with building an AMD / Ryzen PC, But don't let fanboys tell you Intel is Inferior when it comes to performance...

title: 8700K better value

title: I miss the threads ... But excellent processor.
content: It is clear that many, like I miss the threads to which Intel had accustomed us in their processors of the series i, but that changed in the 9th generation and in this i7-9700K.While it is true that it is a powerful processor and performs well for everything I do, in synthetic tests I score less than its predecessor i7-8700K, which has Hyper-Threading technology, at the time I thought it would be the same 6 cores and 12 threads to 8 cores, but I'm wrong.Let's talk about the temperatures ...I currently use an air cooling of the MSI brand (MSI Cooling Core Frozr XL), so far it has been working out, although sometimes it reaches 50 degrees without load, but it has never reached the 80 degrees that I would worry about.I emphasize that I still have and use the NZXT H440 cabinet, where this processor is installed, the air flow is not the best, it has two 140mm fans on the front, two 120mm on the top and one on the back, despite how closed it is, it delivers an acceptable air flow to keep this i7-9700k at good temperatures.In short, it did not come out so hot with what the i7-8700K is.About OverClock potential:Having a very limited cooling by air, we could not reach or exceed the mystics 5.1Ghz, our i7-9700K remains stable in the 4.5Ghz with voltage of 1.27v, on a motherboard MSI Z370 Gaming M5 (MSI Z370 GAMING M5 ) with its respective update for support of the 9th generation.According to my tests, if you have a more powerful cooling and an adequate air flow inside the cabinet, and you get a high quality PCB, you could take it beyond the 5.1Ghz.Would you recommend changing from an i7-8700K to an i7-9700K?I will be honest and direct, it would not be convenient to change this processor, since the real power delivered, is very similar to its predecessor, in some programs it yields more and in many others less, in game you will not notice great improvements, not to say null , in itself there is no reason to unpack this amount for a gain of just 3 to 5% in isolated cases.Now, if you are planning to build a PC, then I recommend you go for the latest mature technology in the market and where this i7-9700K processor will be advantageous, advantageous for the life cycle, whether we like it or not, previous generations they are discontinued.But the most important thing is to determine what to use and what budget you have.
